Name: What system of demonstratives is present in the language? (distance-oriented system vs. person-oriented system)

In languages with a person-oriented system (POS), the middle term “denotes a referent close to the hearer” (cf. Diessel 1999:39).

Name: In possessive constructions with a nominal possessor, is the POSSESSOR usually marked? (state most frequent construction; NB: if marking depends on alienability, state marking of possessor in ALIENABLE constructions)
Description: Terminology: pos.marker = possessive marker which is a free or bound form which indicates possession, and which is morphosyntactically associated with a noun denoting possessor. Pers.pos.pref/suf = personal possessive prefix or suffix, is an affix which encodes person, number and/or gender of a possessor and which appears on the possessed noun.  NB: word order of possessor vs. possessed is symbolic, and is specified in a separate section!

Name: In possessive constructions with a nominal possessor, is the POSSESSED noun usually marked? (state most frequent construction; NB: if marking depends on alienability, state marking of possessor in ALIENABLE constructions)
Description: Terminology: pos.marker = possessive marker which is a free or bound form which indicates possession, and which is morphosyntactically associated with a noun denoting possessor. Pers.pos.pref/suf = personal possessive prefix or suffix is an affix which encodes person, number and/or gender of a possessor and which appears on the possessed noun. Possessed = refers to a free or bound form which indicates that an item is possessed and morphosyntactically associated with a noun denoting the possessed entity. NB: word order of possessor vs. possessed is symbolic, and is specified in a separate section!

Name: In possessive constructions with a pronominal possessor, is the POSSESSOR usually marked? (state most frequent construction; NB: if marking depends on alienability, state marking of possessor in ALIENABLE constructions)

Name: In possessive constructions with a pronominal possessor, is the POSSESSED noun usually marked? (state most frequent construction; NB: if marking depends on alienability, state marking of possessor in ALIENABLE constructions)
Description: Terminology: pers.pos.pref/suf = personal possessive prefix or suffix is an affix which encodes person, number and/or gender of a possessor and which appears on the possessed noun. Possessed = refers to a free or bound form which indicates that an item is possessed and morphosyntactically associated with a noun denoting the possessed entity. NB: word order of possessor vs. possessed is symbolic, and is specified in a separate section!
